propositions.text: The narrator observes a peculiar character, the 'Clown', from his study window.
The Clown shakes a Himalayan cedar tree in the dark courtyard.
The Clown's white face is visible through the dense foliage of the cedar.
The courtyard is illuminated by the cold, blue-white moonlight.
The moonlight casts a metallic sheen on the pansies and weeds under the cedar.
The Clown descends from the tree and begins to dance in the pale moonlight.
His wide trousers and sleeves with frills fly in the night wind.
He dances wildly and appears as if possessed by a demon.
The narrator believes the Clown is a madman due to his persistent actions.
The Clown has been dancing, climbing trees, and performing handstands for a while.
He gestures to the narrator to come out, even when his hand is tired.
The narrator admires the Clown's peculiar stubbornness and fervor.
The narrator's wife is impatient and wants to call the police.
The Clown escapes like a hare when the police arrive.
Despite escaping, the Clown calls the narrator and asks about treasure.
The Clown repeatedly calls, undeterred by the police presence.
The Clown reappears after the police leave and continues the cycle of harassment.
The Clown's identity is obscured by his thick makeup, but his agility and voice suggest youth.
Neighbors are curious about the events but are unable to understand what is happening.
The narrator denies knowing the Clown to his wife, despite the Clown's directed actions.
The narrator is certain the Clown is a 'celebrity' in the underground passage of Shinjuku Station's West Exit.
The Clown is regularly seen in the underground passage in the afternoon, collecting discarded newspapers and magazines.
He collects multiple copies of the same publication.
He performs his unique dance moves while walking and collecting.
The narrator initially found the Clown startling but eventually grew accustomed to his presence.
The Clown's existence became as unremarkable as the neon signs in the street.
The Clown's distinctive attire contributes to his nickname.
He wears a jester's hat over brightly colored, multi-hued dyed hair (red and green).
Despite his bizarre appearance, people in the Shinjuku underground passage largely ignore the Clown.
They are either accustomed to him or indifferent.
He is like a transparent person in the indifferent space.
There is a sense of familiarity and even comfort associated with seeing the Clown.
People avoid direct interaction with the Clown, even when offering discarded materials.
The narrator reflects on Tokyo's indifference to outward appearances, where neither flashy nor plain attire garners significant attention.
People's nerves are numbed by the daily tension of urban life.
The narrator admits to his own lack of interest in others' affairs, particularly given his financial troubles with his drama school in Seijo.
The narrator's interactions with the Shinjuku Clown have been limited to observation in the underground passage.
The narrator encounters the Clown outside the underground passage for the first time.
The narrator, feeling weary from fundraising, decides to visit a bookstore after work.
He enters the East Exit underground passage and does not see the Clown in the West Exit.
Tokyo's underground passages are surprisingly crowded even before the evening rush hour.
The narrator observes a child collecting white paper scraps.
Initially, he mistakes the child for an adult dwarf due to their large head.
The child meticulously collects only small white pieces of paper, ignoring larger trash.
The narrator is moved by the child's seemingly selfless service.
The narrator follows the child, who is heading towards the bookstore.
The narrator sees the Clown, who is behaving as usual (hopping and dancing).
The narrator is surprised to see the Clown in this location and at this time, considering it might be part of his work for a new store opening.
The Clown continues his dance, attracting attention from passersby.
Men look back, while women and children avoid him with disgusted glances.
The Clown stops at the Mitsukoshi department store's underground entrance and appears to be thinking.
The Clown looks back and briefly stares at the narrator, who fears being discovered.
The Clown enters Mitsukoshi.
The Clown proceeds to a staircase inside the department store.
The narrator discreetly follows, pretending to look at merchandise.
The staircase area is used as a storage space.
The narrator follows the Clown up the stairs, moving quietly.
The Clown stops on the fifth, seventh, and eighth floors, appearing to search for something.
The narrator observes the surroundings but finds nothing unusual.
The Clown moves towards the elevator area on the eighth floor.
The narrator begins to doubt the Clown's purpose, suspecting he is merely wandering aimlessly.
The Clown enters a downward elevator, causing surprise among its occupants.
The narrator misses the elevator and takes another one, tracking its descent.
The Clown's elevator stops at the fourth floor, first floor, and then the basement.
The narrator finds the Clown waiting by the basement staircase, appearing to be contemplating.
People passing by the Clown show expressions of disgust.
The Clown leaves the basement staircase area and heads towards the underground passage.
The Clown proceeds towards Isetan department store, stopping in a passage next to the food exhibition area.
The narrator hides and observes the Clown, who stares motionlessly at the stone wall.
The Clown suddenly moves towards the narrator's location and disappears into an underground entrance.
The narrator follows the Clown to the underground passage, and the Clown heads towards Isetan.
The Clown stops again at Isetan, staring at a stone wall.
The narrator observes from a hidden position near the wall.
After a period of stillness, the Clown moves and heads back towards the narrator's general direction.
The narrator hides behind a pillar.
The Clown passes by the narrator and heads towards the underground train line.
The narrator's interest intensifies, and he continues to follow.
The Clown emerges above ground in front of Hankyu Department Store.
The narrator continues to follow, keeping close to the walls.
The Clown then heads towards Shimbashi.
The Clown suddenly turns back towards the narrator's direction.
The Clown re-enters an underground entrance.
The Clown heads towards Harumi.
The Clown stops in front of a chocolate-colored stone pillar, appearing to be thinking.
At the intersection of Fourth Street, the Clown appears agitated and rushes towards an exit labeled 'a7'.
The narrator follows closely, emboldened by the crowd.
The narrator emerges above ground in front of the Mitsukoshi Department Store.
The Clown again turns towards the narrator's direction, causing the narrator apprehension.
The Clown passes by the narrator without acknowledging him and continues on.
The Clown returns to the underground passage and heads towards Kyobashi.
The Clown ascends an 'a12' exit, pausing in the stairwell.
The narrator waits before following, to avoid being caught.
The Clown emerges above ground and is halted by traffic at a crosswalk.
The narrator witnesses a surreal scene of the isolated Clown amidst the bustling Ginza.
The narrator follows the Clown across the street, who is heading towards Kyobashi.
The Clown stops in front of an old, small hat shop called 'Toraya Hat Shop'.
The narrator is surprised by the existence of such a shop in modern Tokyo.
The shop's appearance evokes a sense of antiquity, resembling the Toyotomi Hideyoshi era.
The Clown contemplates for a long time in front of the hat shop.
The Clown turns towards the narrator's concealed position and disappears into a nearby underground entrance.
The narrator follows into the underground passage and sees the Clown heading back towards Ginza Fourth Street, then towards Hibiya.
The Clown's pace has become heavier, indicating a preoccupation.
The Clown stops again at a ticket machine for the Marunouchi Line and purchases a ticket for a short distance.
The narrator also buys a ticket and follows the Clown into the station.
The Clown boards the train heading towards Ogikubo.
The narrator anticipates the Clown returning to Shinjuku.
The Clown disembarks at Kasumigaseki, only one stop away.
The Clown walks through a long corridor, seemingly towards the Hibiya Line.
The narrator remains cautious, observing the Clown's movements.
The Clown passes through the Hibiya Line platform and continues towards the Chiyoda Line.
The underground area at Kasumigaseki, a junction of three subway lines, is described as a maze.
The narrator follows the Clown through the Chiyoda Line ticket gates and discovers an old, narrow shopping street.
The narrator is surprised by the existence of such an old-fashioned shopping street underground.
They reach the end of the passage, with two stairwells leading to the surface.
The Clown ascends the stairwell labeled 'c4'.
The narrator notices that the Clown is holding a small piece of paper.
The paper seems to be guiding the Clown's actions.
The Clown stops midway up the marble staircase, visible only by his colorful trousers and black shoes.
The Clown stares blankly for a long time, and the narrator waits patiently.
The narrator anticipates the Clown emerging into the government district and Hibiya Park.
Contrary to expectations, the Clown turns back and descends the stairs.
The narrator experiences genuine panic, finding himself alone in the deserted shopping street.
The sound of the Clown's shoes echoes.
The narrator quickly ducks into a coffee shop in the shopping street.
He pretends to be looking for someone while observing the Clown's movements through the window.
When the Clown passes, the narrator rushes out of the coffee shop and follows him back into the underground passage.
The Clown stops at a ticket machine for the Hibiya Line and enters the ticket gate.
The narrator follows him into the Hibiya Line train.
The Clown stands in the crowded train, holding a strap, with no one on either side of him.
The Clown disembarks at Ebisu and proceeds towards the ground.
It is dusk, and the air is cold.
The Clown heads towards the JR ticket gate, seemingly to transfer to the Yamanote Line.
The narrator is tired of the aimless tracking and the mysterious Clown's behavior.
The Clown boards a train heading towards Ikebukuro.
The narrator boards the same train.
The train passes Shibuya and Harajuku, approaching Shinjuku.
The narrator decides to end his pursuit in Shinjuku.
The Clown does not disembark at Shinjuku, remaining on the train.
The narrator, confused, boards the train again to continue following.
He closes the distance to the Clown amidst the crowded train.
Passengers actively avoid the Clown, displaying expressions of disgust.
A foul odor emanates from the Clown, a mix of sweat and dirt.
The narrator and other passengers feel a sense of profound misfortune and a heightened sense of their own luck.
The narrator briefly forgets his financial worries, grateful for his stable life.
The Clown disembarks at Ikebukuro with the large crowd, carrying the 'unfortunate smell'.
The narrator follows the Clown towards the East Exit ticket gates.
They wait for the traffic light to cross.
The Clown heads to the underground staircase entrance in front of Mitsukoshi Department Store.
He pauses at the staircase.
The Clown then proceeds to the elevator in front of Seibu Department Store.
The Clown enters an elevator to the eleventh floor, which leads to a large bookstore.
The narrator feels relieved to find a bookstore and abandons his pursuit.
The narrator buys two books on drama theory and one on stock investment, concluding his 'adventure'.
The narrator returns to his home in Okubo.
The next day, Saturday, the narrator needs to go to Ginza for financial matters.
On his way, he sees a well-dressed old gentleman staring intently at an old-fashioned shop.
The narrator recognizes the shop as the hat shop where the Clown was contemplating.
The old gentleman is wearing a black top hat, a white shirt, and gold-rimmed glasses.
The old gentleman, leaning on a cane, is engrossed in observing the shop's exterior.
The narrator becomes curious and begins to follow the old gentleman.
The old gentleman crosses the street, waiting for the traffic light.
The narrator follows him into the underground passage near Matsuya Department Store.
The narrator is surprised to find himself at 'a12', the same staircase the Clown stopped at.
The old gentleman spends a considerable amount of time examining the black and white stone wall.
The narrator has a strong premonition that something inexplicable is happening.
He feels a sense of unease and fear in the city, as if it has become an unknown world.
The old gentleman proceeds to 'a7' exit and studies the green marble walls.
He then returns to the underground passage and heads towards the Hibiya Line entrance, stopping at a chocolate-colored stone pillar.
The old gentleman enters the Marunouchi Line ticket gates and boards a train towards Kasumigaseki.
The narrator is certain the old gentleman is following the same route as the Clown.
The narrator suspects the old gentleman will alight at Kasumigaseki and proceed to the 'c4' exit.
The narrator hesitates to speak to the old gentleman due to respect.
The old gentleman disembarks at Kasumigaseki and walks towards the long underground corridor.
The narrator finally summons the courage to speak to the old gentleman.
He asks if the old gentleman is heading to the 'c4' staircase.
The old gentleman confirms and replies, 'Treasure hunting! This is a treasure mountain!'
The narrator is stunned by the mention of 'treasure hunting'.
The old gentleman leaves abruptly, saying 'Excuse me'.
On his way home, the narrator sees the Clown in the Shinjuku West Exit underground passage, searching for magazines.
Feeling a bit more cheerful due to having secured some funds, the narrator approaches the Clown.
He asks the Clown, 'Have you already given up on 'treasure hunting'?'
The Clown is startled and asks, 'What do you mean?'
The narrator cryptically suggests that locations like Shinjuku Mitsukoshi, various Ginza underground passages, and the 'c4' exit at Kasumigaseki are 'treasure hunting' routes.
The Clown's expression changes, and he begins to follow the narrator.
The narrator, feeling regret for speaking to the Clown, senses the Clown's gaze following him.
The Clown appears at the narrator's house at night, dancing and climbing trees.
He taps on the window and gestures for the narrator to come out.
The narrator's wife is terrified and repeatedly asks for an explanation.
The Clown calls the narrator, his tone卑屈 (humble/servile), asking about 'treasure hunting'.
The narrator realizes the Clown believes he knows something.
The narrator himself is confused about the Clown's actions and identity.
The wife calls the police, causing the Clown to flee, only to return when the police leave.
The next day, Sunday, the narrator's wife insists on accompanying him due to safety concerns.
They decide to have a meal and watch a movie.
While walking in Hibiya Park, the narrator is drawn to the 'c4' exit at Kasumigaseki.
He recalls the exit numbers the Clown visited: c3 (Hankyu), a7 (Ginza Mitsukoshi), a12 (Matsuya), and c4 (Kasumigaseki).
He speculates these numbers might be a code.
He lists the floors the Clown stopped at in Shinjuku Mitsukoshi (4th, 1st, 5th, 7th, 8th) and Isetan (1st).
He lists the Clown's later movements in Ikebukuro (Seibu 11th floor).
The narrator finds no discernible pattern in these numbers.
The narrator tells his wife he wants to go to the underground passage.
He notes that the 'c4' exit is also labeled 'Iino Building Exit'.
Descending the stairs, the narrator observes a beautiful young woman (around 35) also seemingly 'treasure hunting'.
The woman stands by the marble wall and begins to cry.
She then moves towards the Chiyoda Line direction.
The narrator follows her, prompting his wife's dissatisfaction.
The woman enters the Chiyoda Line, then proceeds to the Marunouchi Line, heading towards Ginza.
She boards the train to Ginza and appears to have stopped crying.
The wife's dissatisfaction intensifies, urging him to abandon the pursuit for their movie.
In Ginza, the woman exits the Marunouchi Line and heads towards the Hankyu Department Store staircase.
She stops at the same chocolate-colored stone pillar as the old gentleman and the Clown.
The narrator realizes the woman is following the exact same route and stops at the same locations.
He speculates they are all seeking treasure.
The woman proceeds towards the 'a7' exit at the Fourth Street intersection.
The narrator stops following at the 'a7' exit, expecting her to return.
A group of burly men in black suits descends the 'a7' staircase.
They exude an atmosphere of preparedness and intimidation.
The men head towards Kyobashi, then ascend the 'a12' staircase.
The narrator is shocked by the scale of the 'treasure hunt' and the involvement of organized crime.
He and his wife follow them towards the Toraya Hat Shop.
The wife's frustration boils over, and the narrator abandons the chase.
The narrator regrets leaving possible riches and the chance to save his drama school.
After the movie, the narrator hopes to find the Clown in the Shinjuku West Exit underground passage.
He fails to find the Clown.
The narrator is eager for the Clown's reappearance, hoping to join the treasure hunt to alleviate his financial woes.
He falls asleep disappointed by the Clown's absence.
On his way to work, the narrator overhears two men discussing the Clown.
One man states the Clown is wealthy and involved in real estate and land deals.
He attributes this wealth to 'Asari-zuke' (gambling or a special investment).
The second man asks about 'Asari-zuke', and the first man calls it a 'treasure mountain'.
The narrator is alarmed, realizing the Clown's treasure hunt is yielding results and the information is leaking.
Driven by his financial desperation, the narrator decides to approach the Clown again.
He finds the Clown searching through trash cans.
He directly asks the Clown about the successful 'treasure hunting'.
The Clown is startled and emits a foul odor.
The narrator reminds the Clown of his previous visit to his house and his waiting.
The narrator suggests they talk privately.
The Clown silently follows the narrator.
The narrator confronts the Clown, stating he knows about the treasure hunt and the other individuals involved at specific locations.
He offers his expertise in solving mysteries and suggests a partnership.
The Clown, cautious, asks who else the narrator has seen searching.
The narrator describes the men in black suits, the old gentleman, and the beautiful woman.
The narrator presses for information about the treasure.
The Clown, fearing the narrator might try to steal the treasure, states, 'It's not too late yet...'.
The Clown confirms they are treasure hunting in Tokyo, guided by a paper with locations.
He asks for the narrator's help.
The narrator agrees, provided he is allowed to join.
The Clown says he has other matters to attend to and suggests meeting again at the same spot at 6 PM that evening.
The narrator agrees, though slightly displeased by the late meeting time.
At 6 PM, the narrator waits for the Clown at the designated spot.
The Clown arrives late.
The Clown observes the narrator's eagerness for money.
The Clown reveals that the treasure is money, possibly fifty million or one hundred million yen.
He explains that a gangster stole the money from his organization and hid it in Tokyo before attempting to flee.
The gangster was killed after his hiding place was discovered by the organization.
The money has not been found.
This event occurred last month, and the gangster was killed in Harumi.
The narrator is anxious to find the money, given the circumstances.
The narrator questions if the money is still in Tokyo and if anyone else knows.
The Clown confirms the money was hidden less than an hour before the gangster's death.
The narrator wonders why the search is focused on Ginza and Shinjuku if the money might be near Harumi.
The Clown produces the paper with the list of locations, found on the gangster.
The paper contains a list of places the Clown and others have been following.
The narrator understands why everyone is lingering at these specific spots.

concepts.name: Clown
concepts.context: A mysterious character in thick makeup who dances, collects trash, and is involved in a treasure hunt.

concepts.name: Treasure Hunting
concepts.context: The central mystery of the story, involving a large sum of money hidden in Tokyo.

concepts.name: Narrator
concepts.context: The protagonist, facing financial difficulties with his drama school, who becomes obsessed with the treasure hunt.

concepts.name: Underground Passage
concepts.context: Key locations where the Clown and others are observed, particularly in Shinjuku and Ginza.

concepts.name: Locations
concepts.context: Specific places like department stores (Mitsukoshi, Isetan, Seibu, Hankyu), train stations (Shinjuku, Kasumigaseki), and a hat shop, marked by numbers or letters (a7, a12, c4).

concepts.name: Money
concepts.context: The ultimate goal of the treasure hunt, a significant sum stolen by a gangster.

concepts.name: Wife
concepts.context: The narrator's wife, who is concerned about his obsessive behavior and safety.

concepts.name: Paper/Note
concepts.context: A piece of paper containing a list of locations, crucial for guiding the treasure hunt.

concepts.name: Old Gentleman
concepts.context: Another character involved in the treasure hunt, following the same routes as the Clown.

concepts.name: Beautiful Woman
concepts.context: A third character pursuing the treasure, exhibiting similar behavior to the Clown and the old gentleman.

concepts.name: Men in Black Suits
concepts.context: A group associated with organized crime, also participating in the treasure hunt.

concepts.name: Drama School
concepts.context: The narrator's struggling institution, the motivation behind his desire for the treasure.

concepts.name: Calls
concepts.context: The Clown's persistent phone calls to the narrator, demanding information.

concepts.name: Dance
concepts.context: The Clown's peculiar mannerism, performed while moving and collecting.

concepts.name: Stone Pillar
concepts.context: Specific points where characters pause and contemplate during the treasure hunt.

concepts.name: Stairs
concepts.context: Specific staircases (a7, a12, c4) are significant points in the treasure hunt route.

concepts.name: Hat Shop
concepts.context: The Toraya Hat Shop, a location where characters pause and ponder.

concepts.name: Shopping Street
concepts.context: An old-fashioned underground shopping street at Kasumigaseki, part of the treasure hunt route.

concepts.name: Asari-zuke
concepts.context: A term mentioned by two men, potentially related to gambling or a secret of the Clown's wealth.

concepts.name: Gangster
concepts.context: The individual who stole and hid the treasure money before being killed.

hierarchy.structure: The document is structured as a narrative, unfolding through observations, encounters, and a developing mystery. It progresses chronologically, with chapters marking distinct phases of the narrator's investigation into the treasure hunt and the characters involved. The narrative shifts from observation to active involvement and speculation.
